nodes.label: 100–200 nm nanoplastics
nodes.definition_notes: Shard- or flake-like nanoplastics with lengths largely <200 nm and widths <40 nm, observed in pellets from liver, kidney, and brain.

nodes.label: 1–5 µm microparticles
nodes.definition_notes: Rod-shaped or shard-like refractile inclusions of 1–5 µm observed in liver and kidney by microscopy; not seen in brain.

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Irregular shard or flake morphology of nanoplastics in human tissues, commonly <200 nm length.
nodes.artifact_notes: Microscopy limited in resolving the smallest particles; aggregation and residual biomatrix may affect appearance.

nodes.label: brain
nodes.histology_notes: Frontal cortex parenchyma with cerebrovascular walls and immune cell infiltrates; particulate inclusions observed in parenchyma and vascular walls, especially in dementia cases.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Potential susceptibility related to blood–brain barrier integrity and clearance mechanisms; dementia cases show hallmarks like atrophy and impaired barrier.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.histology_notes: Right central liver parenchyma with refractile inclusions aggregated within regions resembling lipid droplets.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Potential aggregation of nanoplastics in hepatic lipid droplets; tissue shows carbon-rich particulate inclusions.

nodes.label: kidney
nodes.histology_notes: Wedge pieces including cortex and medulla; refractile inclusions observed in glomeruli and along tubules.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Aggregation and distribution of carbon-rich particulates in renal structures.

nodes.label: dementia
nodes.population: decedent human brain cohort with Alzheimer's disease, vascular dementia, or other dementia diagnoses
nodes.notes: Brains from decedent dementia cases showed substantially higher microplastic concentrations than normal brains; data are associative and do not establish causality.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Hypothesized mechanisms for nanoplastic uptake into the brain include clathrin-dependent endocytosis and macropinocytosis analogous to observations in Daphnia magna, and possible transport linked to lipid ingestion; routes of exposure, uptake, and clearance pathways remain poorly understood.

nodes.name: unspecified_plastic_biomarker
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: The study does not report specific molecular biomarkers such as cytokines or oxidative stress markers; primary measurements are polymer mass concentrations.

nodes.assumptions_notes: Study highlights need to understand routes of exposure and suggests that ingestion of lipids may facilitate selective nanoplastic transfer into the brain; precise pathway is not empirically characterized.

nodes.notes: Polyethylene pellets and fragments used as virgin and marine-deployed plastic in dietary exposure for medaka; pellets were 3 mm prior to grinding and <0.5 mm after grinding and sieving.

geo_context.region: University of California, Davis aquatic facility

location.region: Coronado Cays Yacht Club, San Diego Bay

nodes.sample_prep: Virgin LDPE pellets deployed in nylon mesh bags from a floating dock for 3 months; rinsed, dried, ground, sieved to <0.5 mm.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate grinders and cleaning with acetone and hexane to avoid cross-contamination.
nodes.storage_conditions: -20 C after recovery from marine deployment.
nodes.notes: LDPE pellets deployed in San Diego Bay to sorb PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs prior to use in marine-plastic treatment diet.

nodes.sample_prep: Virgin LDPE pellets rinsed, dried, ground, sieved to <0.5 mm.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate grinder and solvent rinsing to avoid procedural contamination.
nodes.storage_conditions: Room temperature before grinding; storage not specified after grinding.
nodes.notes: Pre-production LDPE pellets not deployed in the marine environment, used in virgin-plastic treatment diet.

nodes.sample_prep: Mixed diet with 0% plastic by weight; contained vitamin-free casein, wheat gluten, dextrin, egg albumin, soy lecithin, vitamin and mineral premix, corn oil, cod liver oil, celufil.
nodes.contamination_controls: Pre-cleaned mixing surfaces and dishes; separate from plastic diets.
nodes.storage_conditions: Prepared prior to experiment; specific storage not described.
nodes.notes: Negative control diet containing PAHs, PCBs, PBDEs from cod liver oil but no LDPE fragments.

nodes.sample_prep: As control diet but with 10% by weight ground virgin LDPE substituted for dextrin.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate pre-cleaned dishes for each diet; mixed on pre-cleaned surfaces.
nodes.storage_conditions: Prepared before 2-month exposure; storage not specified.
nodes.notes: Virgin-plastic treatment diet containing ground LDPE fragments (~0.5 mm) and background PAHs, PCBs, PBDEs.

nodes.sample_prep: As control diet but with 10% by weight ground LDPE deployed 3 months in San Diego Bay, sieved to <0.5 mm.
nodes.contamination_controls: Separate dishes; pre-cleaned equipment; activated charcoal filters in tank system to limit background contamination.
nodes.storage_conditions: Prepared before exposure; storage not specified.
nodes.notes: Marine-plastic treatment diet exposing fish to higher concentrations of PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs via sorbed contaminants on LDPE.

nodes.sample_prep: Three replicate water samples collected post-experiment for PBT analysis.
nodes.contamination_controls: Activated charcoal filters used and changed twice per month; LDPE not allowed into recirculating system during feedings.
nodes.storage_conditions: Not specified.
nodes.notes: No detectable PBTs in post-experiment tank water, suggesting diet was primary exposure route.

nodes.sample_prep: Pooled ~14 medaka per tank to obtain 5 g tissue sample at 1-month; prepared for PAH, PCB, PBDE analysis.
nodes.contamination_controls: Standard QA/QC in chemical analysis; details in supplementary methods.
nodes.storage_conditions: Fish euthanized with MS-222 before sampling; tissue handling per toxicology protocols.
nodes.notes: Used to quantify early bioaccumulation of PAHs, PCBs, PBDEs after 1 month of dietary exposure.

nodes.sample_prep: Three pooled 5 g samples per tank at 2 months, prepared for PAH, PCB, PBDE analysis.
nodes.contamination_controls: QA/QC as described in supplementary methods; ANOVA performed on log-transformed data.
nodes.storage_conditions: Fish euthanized with MS-222; tissues processed for chemical analysis.
nodes.notes: Used to quantify bioaccumulation of PBTs after 2-month chronic exposure; showed higher PBDE levels in marine-plastic group.

nodes.sample_prep: Livers from six male and six female medaka per tank pooled by sex, total RNA isolated, DNase treated, cDNA synthesized for RT-qPCR.
nodes.contamination_controls: Multiple reference genes used (GAPDH, β-actin, 18S rRNA); Ct values averaged from triplicates.
nodes.storage_conditions: Livers stored at -80 C prior to RNA extraction.
nodes.notes: Used to assess hepatic CYP1A gene expression after 1 and 2 months of exposure.

nodes.sample_prep: Eight fish per tank fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin, dehydrated, paraffin embedded, 3 µm sections stained with hematoxylin and eosin.
nodes.contamination_controls: Standard histological processing; some fish lost due to methodological error.
nodes.storage_conditions: Fixed and embedded samples stored under standard histology conditions.
nodes.notes: Used to score liver histopathology including glycogen depletion, fatty vacuolation, single-cell necrosis, and neoplastic lesions at 2 months.

nodes.label: fragment
nodes.definition_notes: Irregular particles produced by grinding LDPE pellets and sieving to <0.5 mm; observed in medaka gastrointestinal tract and feces during exposure.
nodes.artifact_notes: Ground in laboratory; care taken to avoid contamination but fragmentation is artificial relative to environmental mechanical breakdown.

nodes.label: <0.5 mm_fragments
nodes.definition_notes: Size class corresponding to LDPE fragments collected using sieves to obtain particles smaller than 0.5 mm for dietary exposure.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Chronic ingestion of LDPE with sorbed PBTs leads to hepatic stress including glycogen depletion, fatty vacuolation, necrosis and neoplastic lesions indicating complex toxic mechanisms including metabolic disturbance and possibly oxidative stress.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.histology_notes: Livers showed severe glycogen depletion, fatty vacuolation, single-cell necrosis, eosinophilic focus of cellular alteration and hepatocellular adenoma in fish exposed to virgin and marine LDPE diets.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Central organ for metabolism and detoxification of xenobiotics; hepatic damage may hinder detoxification mechanisms including AhR-mediated responses.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Site of plastic ingestion and initial contact with LDPE fragments and sorbed contaminants; plastic observed in gastrointestinal tract.

nodes.name: CYP1A mRNA expression

nodes.name: hepatic glycogen depletion
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Severe glycogen depletion observed in a high proportion of fish exposed to LDPE diets, particularly marine-plastic treatment, indicates hepatic metabolic stress linked to exposure to organochlorinated xenobiotics.

nodes.name: hepatic fatty vacuolation
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Fatty vacuolar degeneration in liver cells indicates potential progression to fatty liver degeneration associated with exposure to contaminants such as PCBs.

nodes.name: single-cell hepatocellular necrosis
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Presence of single-cell necrosis in livers of fish exposed to marine LDPE diet indicates cytotoxic injury associated with plastic and sorbed contaminants.

nodes.name: preneoplastic and neoplastic hepatic lesions
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Observation of eosinophilic focus of cellular alteration and hepatocellular adenoma in exposed fish suggests early carcinogenic processes related to plastic exposure; such lesions are rare in young medaka without exposure.

nodes.label: hepatic_toxicity
nodes.notes: Chronic dietary exposure to LDPE, particularly marine-deployed LDPE with sorbed PBTs, induces hepatic toxicity in medaka, evidenced by histological liver damage and lesion formation.

nodes.label: liver_tumor
nodes.notes: A hepatocellular adenoma occupying 25% of the liver observed in one fish from the marine-plastic treatment, and a preneoplastic eosinophilic focus in a virgin-plastic fish, indicate potential tumorigenic outcomes from chronic plastic ingestion.

nodes.label: PBT_concentrations_in_treatment_diets
nodes.notes: Marine-plastic and virgin-plastic treatment diets showed higher total PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs than control diet; marine-plastic diet particularly enriched in PCBs and PBDEs.

nodes.label: PBT_body_burden_after_2_months
nodes.notes: Medaka exposed to marine-plastic diet had greater concentrations of total PAHs, PCBs and PBDEs than control fish after 2 months; PBDEs and specific congeners (chrysene, PCB28) significantly higher.

nodes.label: hepatic_CYP1A_expression_patterns

nodes.label: liver_histopathological_changes

nodes.notes: Polystyrene nanoplastics of nominal primary size ~25 nm and density 1.05 g/cm3 were used as fluorescently labelled particles in larval zebrafish exposure experiments.

nodes.sample_prep: Larval zebrafish were exposed individually in 24- or 48-well plates containing defined volumes of egg water with suspended PSNPs, with medium exchange once during exposure.
nodes.contamination_controls: Particle control experiment using TiO2 nanoparticles matched by particle number to PSNPs; solvent controls for mifepristone and glucose were included.
nodes.storage_conditions: Larvae maintained at 28.5±0.5 °C in incubators with defined light–dark cycles until sampling; specific storage conditions for post-collection samples varied by assay.
nodes.collector: Institute of Environmental Sciences (CML), Leiden University
nodes.notes: Embryos and larvae (Danio rerio) were exposed from 72 to 120 h post-fertilisation in egg water with polystyrene nanoplastics, with additional co-exposures to glucose and mifepristone in some assays.

nodes.label: nanoplastic_approx_25_nm
nodes.definition_notes: Nominal hydrodynamic diameter of polystyrene nanoplastic particles in egg water was approximately 19–25 nm as assessed by TEM and DLS in previous work referenced in the study.

nodes.label: other
nodes.definition_notes: Polystyrene nanoplastics were supplied as nominally spherical nanoparticles.

nodes.label: other

emission_rate_estimate.context: Nominal highest exposure concentration in egg water from 72 to 120 hpf for PSNPs.

nodes.notes: Fluorescent polystyrene nanoplastics were intentionally added to exposure media to model nanoplastic exposure; they are a primary micro/nanoplastic source rather than degradation products.

nodes.label: gut
nodes.histology_notes: Includes gastrointestinal tract of larvae at 72–120 hpf where PSNP accumulation was observed in the intestine lumen and epithelium.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Gastrointestinal tract serves as major accumulation and potential translocation site for nanoplastics following ingestion.

nodes.label: liver
nodes.histology_notes: Hepatic tissue is involved in glucose and lipid metabolism; gene expression markers such as fgf21, g6pca, ldha were measured in whole larvae, reflecting hepatic metabolic regulation.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Liver is a key metabolic organ sensitive to nanoplastic-induced disruption of energy metabolism.

nodes.label: other
nodes.histology_notes: Exocrine and endocrine pancreas in developing zebrafish are closely associated; PSNP accumulation was reported in the exocrine pancreas, and insulin-expressing endocrine pancreas was assessed by in situ hybridisation.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Pancreatic tissues regulating insulin secretion and digestion are implicated in nanoplastic-induced alterations of glucose homeostasis.

nodes.label: brain
nodes.histology_notes: Brain receives signals related to glucose status and cortisol, integrating HPI-axis activation and behavioural outputs such as locomotor activity during dark challenges.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Neural circuits mediating stress and locomotor responses may be affected indirectly via cortisol and metabolic disruption in PSNP-exposed larvae.

nodes.label: blood
nodes.histology_notes: Whole-body homogenates used for glucose and cortisol quantification integrate contributions from circulating blood and tissues.
nodes.vulnerability_notes: Circulating cortisol and glucose levels reflect systemic stress and metabolic status during PSNP exposure.

nodes.label: metabolic_disturbance
nodes.notes: Polystyrene nanoplastic exposure decreased whole-body glucose levels, altered expression of gluconeogenic (pck1, g6pca) and metabolic regulators (fgf21, ldha), and reduced insulin-expressing domain size, indicating disruption of glucose homeostasis and energy metabolism.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: PSNP exposure increased whole-body cortisol levels in wild-type larvae in a dose-dependent manner and downregulated expression of the serotonin transporter gene slc6a4, suggesting HPI-axis activation and potential neuromodulatory changes.

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: A bottom-up chain of events was proposed where PSNP accumulation in pancreas and gut reduces glucose, which stimulates cortisol secretion through glucocorticoid receptor activation and leads to altered locomotor behaviour under dark challenge.

nodes.name: glucose
nodes.threshold_unit: mg/L PSNP (nominal exposure concentration associated with significant decrease)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased glucose levels indicate disruption of energy metabolism and may act as a trigger for stress-axis activation.

nodes.name: cortisol
nodes.threshold_unit: mg/L PSNP (lowest concentration with significant increase)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Elevated cortisol is a hallmark of stress response in fish and is implicated in modulation of behaviour and metabolism.

nodes.name: pck1 promoter activity
nodes.tissue_matrix: whole larval zebrafish with liver- and kidney-localised promoter activity
nodes.threshold_unit: mg/L PSNP (lowest tested with increased activity)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase 1 promoter activity reflects enhanced gluconeogenesis in response to disrupted glucose homeostasis.

nodes.name: g6pca (glucose-6-phosphatase a) expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Upregulated glucose-6-phosphatase indicates activation of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenic processes.

nodes.name: fgf21 expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Fibroblast growth factor 21 plays a role in hepatic lipid and glucose homeostasis; increased expression suggests altered metabolic regulation.

nodes.name: ldha expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced lactate dehydrogenase a expression points to altered anaerobic glycolysis under PSNP exposure.

nodes.name: slc6a4 expression
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Downregulation of serotonin transporter (slc6a4) suggests altered serotonergic signalling that may contribute to behavioural changes.

nodes.name: insulin expression domain size
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced insulin-expressing area in the pancreas indicates impaired endocrine function associated with disturbed glucose regulation.

nodes.label: locomotor_hyperactivity_dark_challenge
nodes.population: larval zebrafish (wild-type ABTL and gr strains) exposed from 72–120 hpf
nodes.notes: PSNP-exposed wild-type larvae exhibited increased distance moved during dark challenge phases in an alternating light–dark test, whereas this hyperactivity was absent in glucocorticoid receptor mutant larvae and under glucose co-exposure or mifepristone treatment.

nodes.label: reduced_swim_bladder_inflation
nodes.population: larval zebrafish (wild-type and gr mutants) exposed from 72–120 hpf
nodes.notes: A lower proportion of PSNP-exposed larvae had inflated swim bladders compared to controls, suggesting developmental effects on swim bladder inflation independent of glucocorticoid receptor activity.

nodes.population_context: developing zebrafish larvae in laboratory conditions
nodes.assumptions_notes: Exposure initiated post-hatching at 72 hpf to avoid chorion barrier, with ingestion and epithelial contact in egg water containing suspended PSNPs; particles also contact outer epithelia early in development.

nodes.notes: Observation of PSNP biodistribution showing accumulation in intestine, exocrine pancreas, and gallbladder after exposure from 72 to 120 hpf.
Increased whole-body cortisol levels in wild-type larvae exposed to PSNPs in a dose-dependent manner, not observed in glucocorticoid receptor mutants or under glucose co-exposure.
Decreased whole-body glucose levels at the highest PSNP exposure concentration, with strain- and treatment-dependent modulation by glucocorticoid receptor status and mifepristone co-exposure.
Dose-dependent increase in pck1 promoter-driven luciferase activity with PSNP exposure, partially suppressed by glucocorticoid receptor antagonist mifepristone.
qPCR-based changes in expression of metabolic and serotonin-related genes (g6pca, fgf21 upregulated; ldha and slc6a4 downregulated) after PSNP exposure.
Reduction in size of insulin expression domain in PSNP-exposed larvae as shown by in situ hybridisation.

PSNP-exposed wild-type larvae showed increased distance moved during dark challenges, whereas particle control TiO2, glucocorticoid receptor mutants, and glucose or mifepristone co-exposures did not show this hyperactivity.

Title: Polystyrene nanoplastics disrupt glucose metabolism and cortisol levels with a possible link to behavioural changes in larval zebrafish

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: PS-NPs exposure decreased GSH and SOD levels and reduced Nrf2-positive cells in PFC, consistent with oxidative stress; NAC treatment reversed these effects.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: oxidative_stress
nodes.notes: In SH-SY5Y cells, PS-NPs decreased GSH and SOD; NAC co-treatment restored antioxidant markers.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Neuronal cuproptosis characterized by increased cerebral copper, upregulated FDX1, LIAS, DLAT, HSP70, reduced lipoylated DLAT and its oligomerization, and mitochondrial damage in PFC after PS-NPs exposure.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: PS-NPs induced cuproptosis-like changes in SH-SY5Y cells with increased cuprous copper and altered cuproptosis markers; effects mitigated by copper chelator TTM and NAC.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: Oxidative stress-activated ERK-MAPK signaling contributes to PS-NPs-induced cuproptosis in SH-SY5Y cells; ERK inhibitor PD98059 reduced p-ERK, normalized cuproptosis markers, and improved cell viability.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.label: other
nodes.notes: In PFC, PS-NPs exposure activated ERK-MAPK signaling (increased p-ERK); NAC treatment reduced ERK phosphorylation and attenuated cuproptosis-associated changes.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: GSH
nodes.assay_type: Commercial glutathione assay kit (Beyotime, China) in tissue homogenates and cell lysates.
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse brain/PFC homogenate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decrease indicates oxidative stress associated with PS-NPs exposure; NAC restored GSH levels in vivo and in vitro.

nodes.name: SOD activity

nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse brain/PFC homogenate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Reduced SOD activity reflects oxidative stress in brain and neuronal cells after PS-NPs exposure; NAC reversed SOD depletion.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Nrf2-positive cell count
nodes.assay_type: Immunohistochemistry for Nrf2 in PFC sections.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased Nrf2 staining after PS-NPs exposure indicates impaired antioxidant response; NAC increased Nrf2-positive cells.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: Tissue copper content
nodes.assay_type: Copper content assay kit measuring absorbance at 580 nm.

nodes.assay_type: Cuprous content fluorescence assay (ex 395 nm, em 480 nm).

citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: FDX1 protein level

citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: LIAS protein level
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased LIAS supports enhanced lipoylation activity associated with cuproptosis.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: DLAT protein and lipoylated DLAT oligomers
nodes.assay_type: Western blot and immunofluorescence for DLAT and lipoylated DLAT.
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate and sections; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: PS-NPs increased total DLAT and caused oligomerization with decreased monomeric lipoylated DLAT, a hallmark of cuproptosis; NAC and PD98059 reduced oligomerization.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: HSP70 protein level
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Elevated HSP70 reflects proteotoxic stress associated with cuproptosis after PS-NPs exposure.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: p-ERK/ERK ratio
nodes.assay_type: Western blot for ERK and phospho-ERK.
nodes.tissue_matrix: Mouse PFC lysate; SH-SY5Y cell lysate.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Increased ERK phosphorylation indicates activation of ERK-MAPK signaling; NAC and PD98059 reduced p-ERK levels, linking ERK activation to oxidative stress and cuproptosis.
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

nodes.name: SLC31A1 mRNA
nodes.tissue_matrix: SH-SY5Y cells; PFC transcript levels reported.
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Upregulation of copper transporter SLC31A1 mRNA suggests enhanced copper influx contributing to cuproptosis in PS-NPs-exposed cells.

nodes.name: Neuronal viability (CCK-8 absorbance)
nodes.clinical_relevance_notes: Decreased absorbance indicates PS-NPs-induced cytotoxicity; rescued by NAC, TTM, and PD98059, consistent with oxidative stress, copper overload, and ERK-MAPK-mediated cuproptosis.

nodes.assumptions_notes: Mice gavaged daily with 12.5 mg/kg/day 60 nm PS-NPs for 30 days; dose derived from human equivalent microplastics intake scaling based on body surface area.

citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology
nodes.notes: PS-NPs exposure impaired learning and memory in mice as shown by reduced novel object preference index, decreased Y-maze alternation rate, longer escape latency, and fewer platform crossings and shorter time in target quadrant in Morris water maze; NAC mitigated these deficits.

nodes.label: neurotoxicity
nodes.population: C57BL/6 male mice and SH-SY5Y neuronal cells
citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology

citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology
nodes.notes: PS-NPs exposure reduced synapse number and postsynaptic density thickness in PFC; NAC increased synaptic metrics, suggesting functional synaptic impairment and rescue.

citations_ref: Chen et al. 2025 Particle and Fibre Toxicology
nodes.notes: PS-NPs induced neuronal loss in PFC and reduced SH-SY5Y viability; linked mechanistically to cuproptosis via copper dyshomeostasis and ERK-MAPK activation.

attributes.description: Daphnia-conditioned medium contains proteins up to ~435 µg/mL at 6 h, leading to increased hydrodynamic size and polydispersity of NH2-PS NPs and destabilization/agglomeration.

COOH-PS NPs incubated in Daphnia-conditioned medium show decreased EC50 for survival (0.0363 to 0.0337 mg/mL at 6 h conditioning; to 0.0095 mg/mL after longer incubation), and NH2-PS NPs show similar EC50 decreases with conditioning and incubation.

Fluorescent COOH-PS NPs are taken up into Daphnia magna neonates in a time-dependent manner and remain confined to the gut; ~15% of dose remains after 6 h post-exposure for unconditioned NPs and ~20% for eco-corona-coated NPs.
Daphnia magna neonates previously exposed to eco-corona-coated COOH-PS NPs show a trend towards reduced feeding on algae over 6 h compared to controls.

Title: Secreted protein eco-corona mediates uptake and impacts of polystyrene nanoparticles on Daphnia magna
